qas.question: What group of scientists seek to measure the amounts of oxygen in marine animals?
About what weather feature do paleoclimatologists want information ?

answers.text: what the climate was like millions of years ago

qas.question: How much heavier is oxygen 18 than oxygen 16?
What form of oxygen do marine animals acquire in greater amounts during cooler climatic conditions?
During what type of climate is oxygen 18 in seawater at higher levels?
Who measures oxygen-18 and oxygen-16 in skeletons of all organisms?
What is oxygen-16 the lighter one of?
Water higher in oxygen-16 experienced higher what?

context: <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><a0_3><a0_4><b5_0>Paleoclimatologists<b5_0/><a0_4/><a0_3/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> measure the ratio of oxygen-18 and oxygen-16 in the shells and skeletons of marine organisms to determine <a1_4>what the <a1_0><a1_1><a1_3>climate<a1_3/><a1_1/><a1_0/> was like millions of years ago<a1_4/> (see oxygen isotope ratio cycle). Seawater molecules that contain the lighter <b6_0>isotope<b6_0/>, oxygen-16, evaporate at a slightly faster rate than water molecules containing the <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><a2_3><a2_4><b7_0>12%<b7_0/><a2_4/><a2_3/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> heavier oxygen-18; this disparity increases at <a4_2>lower <a1_2>temperatures<a4_2/><a1_2/>. During <a4_1><a4_3>periods of <a4_0><a4_4>lower <b8_0>global temperatures<b8_0/><a4_4/><a4_3/><a4_1/><a4_0/>, snow and rain from that evaporated water tends to be higher in <a3_2>oxygen-16<a3_2/>, and the seawater left behind tends to be higher in <a3_0><a3_1><a3_3><a3_4>oxygen-18<a3_4/><a3_3/><a3_1/><a3_0/>. Marine organisms then incorporate more oxygen-18 into their skeletons and shells than they would in a warmer climate. Paleoclimatologists also directly measure this ratio in the water molecules of ice core samples that are up to several hundreds of thousands of years old.
